Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was elbow-deep in the control panel of the main production unit. The plant manager hovered nearby, his face tight with worry—every minute the line was down cost the company money, and I was the only one who could make sense of the tangled mess of wires and blinking error codes. I wiped my hands on my coveralls and glanced at the screen: a message from my stepdad, just a simple “How’s your weekend going?” I knew he and Mom expected me to check in, to keep the connection alive, especially since I’d moved out. But right now, the pressure to get the machine running again was crushing. I could almost feel the weight of both worlds—my family wanting a sign that I still cared, my boss expecting me to fix the problem, fast. My fingers hovered over the phone, torn between sending a quick reply and diving back into the diagnostics. The hum of the silent factory pressed in on me, and I felt the familiar ache of being pulled in two directions at once.
